awd_titl_txt: Voters, Games, and Epidemics on Random Graphs
awd_abstract_narration:
The main focus of this research will be on spatial random processes. Motivated by applications in ecology we will consider processes that take place in two and three dimensional space. We will also study processes that take place on random graphs, which provide models for social networks. We will consider the spread of information and of diseases through these structures. In addition we will study of the behavior of evolutionary games, which were introduced many years ago to help understand animal behavior and have recently been used to understand the interactions of different cell types in cancer modeling. Despite the fact that it has been clearly established that spatial structure changes the outcome of evolutionary games, most applications assume homogeneous mixing and use the replicator equation to determine the dynamics. Having a well developed theory that predicts the behavior of spatial games will be useful for applications. Much of this theory has been developed under the assumption of weak selection, so it is important to understand whether the results are valid when selection is not weak.

Work will be carried out on evolutionary games, variants of the voter model, coalescing random walk, and epidemics. These processes will in most cases take place on static random graphs generated by the configuration model in which vertices are assigned i.i.d. degrees, but in one situation we will let the states of an SIS epidemic and the graph co-evolve. The degree heterogeneity of random graphs forces the development of new techniques in order to extend results known on the d-dimensional lattice.  In addition,  new phenomena occur on these structures, such as rigorously provable discontinuous phase transitions. Specific research goals include (i) Study the rate of decay of the density of coalescing random walks on a random graph. (ii) Disprove physicists? claim that the critical infection probability on a finite graph is 1 over the largest eigenvalue of the adjacency matrix. (iii) Show that the critical threshold of the SIS is positive if the degree distribution has an exponential tail. (iv) Study SIR and SIS models on evolving graphs where susceptible individuals cut their ties to infected neighbors and rewire to a randomly chosen individual. In the SIR version we want to determine the critical value. In the SIS case we want to show that when the rewiring rate is fixed and the infection rate is varied there is a discontinuous phase transition.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

13 published papers were produced by this grant covering a wide variety of topics. We highlight several that indicate the breadth, depth, and rlevance of the research. An unifying theme in this report is that much of the research was done in Duke’s DOMath summer research experience for undergraduates in the summers of 2022, 2020, and 2018.

 

In the summer of 2022, the deadly Delta covid variant had given way to the more contagious Omicron variant, see Figure 1, but there was still considerable uncertainty about the future as the covid pandemic became endemic. Undergraduates Laura Boyle, Sofia Hletko, Jenny Huang, June Lee, and Gaurav Pallod, did research that led to a paper titled Selective sweeps in SARS-CoV-2 variant competition. The main mathematical result in this paper is that change of variables in the ODE for the competition of two infections in an SIR model shows that the fraction of cases due to the new variant satisfies the logistic differential equation, which models selective sweeps. Fitting the logistic curve to data showed that this correctly predicted the rapid turnover from one dominant variant to another. In addition, our fitting gives sensible estimates of the increase in infectivity. This paper was published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Science.

 

In the summer of 2020, Duke and other universities across the country were wrestling with the question of how to safely welcome students back to campus. Because of this, Molly Borowiak, Fayfay Ning, Justin Pei, Sarah Zhao focused on using mathematical models to evaluate strategies to mitigate the spread of the virus on campus. For dorms, they showed that giving students single rooms rather than double rooms can substantially reduce virus spread. For classrooms, we showed that moving classes with size above some cutoff (which could be 30, 50, or 70 depending on the epidemic parameters) would reduce the epidemic spread and preserve in campus instruction. The paper has appeared in Mathematical Biosciences and Engineering

 

In the summer of 2018, Yufeng Jiang, Remy Kasem, Grayson York, and Brandom Zhao studied the contact process, an SIS epidemic,  on periodic trees. In the Fall of 2018 the first three students listed above continued work begun on the evoSIR model, a modification of the usual SIR process on a graph in which S-I connections are broken at rate ρ and the S individual makes a new connections to a randomly chosen vertex. They computed the critical value for a large outbreak in the model and performed simulation to show that the system has a discontinuous phase transition, i.e., as the infection rate λ decreases to λc, the final fraction of individuals that have been infected does not converge to 0. See Figure 2. About a year later graduate student Dong Yao proved the remarkable result that for graphs generated by the configuration model there is a quantity Δ determined by the first three moments of the degree distribution, so that the transition is discontinuous if Δ >0 and continuous if Δ <0. After more than two years in the refereeing process, the paper has appeared in Electronic Journal of Probability. Subsequent work by Dong and two master’s students has proved the result for the SIR on ERdos-Renyi graphs, completing work of Ball and Brittin.

 

The evoSI paper ranks highest on intellectual merit. A close second is Motion by mean curvature in interacting particle systems by graduate student Xiangying Huang and Rick Durrett. It has long been known that particle systems such as multitype contact processes when rescaled converge to reaction diffusion equations. When the limit speed is positive this can be used to prove results about the phase transition. Builing on results of Etheridge et al we showed that when the speed is 0 and time is further sped up the system comverges to motion by mean curvature. The paper was published in Probability Theory and Related Fields in a collection of papers in honor of Harry Kesten. The convergence result opens up the possibility of proving the existence of two nontrivial translation invariant stationary distributions in part of the phase diagram for the nonlinear voter model studied by Molofsky et al. That research project is still ongoing.

During this grant period the last three of Durrett’s 51 students graduated; Zoe Huang, Dong Yao, and Ray Tung. Ray was the graduate assistant working with the 2022 and 2020 DOMath projects. In his thesis he disproved a conjecture of Chan, Durrett, and Lanchier: three species canot coexist in a model with two seasons, and did an analysis that gave insights into the paradoxical observation that the site frequency of mutations are neutral. He began a postdoc at U. of Utah on July 1, 2023.
